justification: “participants were given the Regulatory Focus Questionnaire (RFQ; Higgins et al., 2001; promotion focus, α=.69), with six items assessing promotion focus”
The authors note they administered “the complete scales (Regulatory Focus Questionnaire …).” RFQ contains the prevention-focus items even though these were not central to the hypotheses.
“Next was the Regulatory Mode Scale (RMS; Kruglanski et al., 2000; assessment, α=.80), with 12 items evaluating assessment…”
Regulatory mode theory “also posits locomotion…we… measured … locomotion mode” by administering the full Regulatory Mode Scale.
The Maximization Scale (MS) is described as containing “13 items (three for high standards …)” and the high-standards score is analysed separately.
The same paragraph states the MS includes “six [items] for alternative search,” indicating this facet is measured by that subscale.
The authors specify the MS has “four [items] for decision difficulty,” treating it as its own measured construct.
“Finally, participants completed the Maximizing Tendency Scale (MTS; Diab et al., 2008; α=.85), with 9 items…” showing the MTS operationalises the overall tendency to maximize.
In Study 3 “we also included the … Maximization Inventory (Turner et al., 2012) along with the MS,” indicating this inventory serves as an additional measure of maximization facets.
